SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.
No. 4
Pioneer Churches.

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name ____________________________
Present Address ____________________________
Pioneer Address ____________________________
Year you came to Saskatchewan _______ _______
(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

(Drawing by Richard Graburn)
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

Pioneer Churches.

1. To what religious services did you go when you first settled in your district?

Where did your neighbors go to church?

How long was it after the first settlers came to your area before services of church worship were organized?

2. By whom were religious services held in your community before a regular church building? If this arrangement, tell who services were held, and give dates if possible.

How was the clergyman supported?

3. Was the school house used for church services? Give dates.

Was it used by congregations of more than one denomination on alternate Sundays?

Did the same congregation ever support both types of services and give equal financial support?

Where did the clergyman (or clergymen) live, and how far was it from the school house?

How did he get to the school house to conduct services?

Was he entertained in homes or supplied with accommodation for the night?

Were services continued throughout the winter months, as well as other seasons of the year?

Who put on the fire for school house services in winter?

What other charges, or appointments, did the clergymen have besides the ones at your school house?

Describe the financial arrangements.

4. Were homes or other buildings such as stores used for church services in your community?

The Church was built about 1890 of concrete. The living room foundation, the walls, and floor away, it didn't last long.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

Pioneer Churches.

1. To what religious services did you go when you first settled in your district?

How did your neighbors go to church?

2. How long was it after the first settlers came to your area before services of church worship were organized?

By whom were religious services held in your community before a regular church became established (or a clergyman from some other place)? Give details of the arrangements, telling where services were held, and give dates if possible.

How was the clergyman supported?

3. Was the school house used for church services? Give dates.

Was it used by congregations of more than one denomination on alternate Sundays?

Did the same congregation ever support both types of services and give equal financial assistance?

Where did the clergyman (or clergymen) live, and how far was it from the school house?

How did he get to the school house to conduct services?

Was he entertained in homes or supplied with accommodation for the night?

Were services continued throughout the winter months, as well as other seasons of the year?

Who put up the fire for school house services in winter?

What other charges, or appointments, did the clergyman have besides the one at your school house?

Describe the financial arrangements.

More than 50 cents fuel kindly

4. Were barns or other buildings used as stores used for church services in your community?

The Church was built about 1890 of concrete. The living room foundation, the walls are gone away. It didn't last long.
5. If you had a church building, give the date it was built. The first R.C. Church was St. Paul's 1903.

Who designed the building? Who built it?

What material was it made of? Wood

How many people did it seat? 300 St. Paul's

6. Describe the steps taken in arranging for the building of the church, telling who started it, how money was secured, etc.

7. How many families were in the congregation at the time of its organization? How many families were in the congregation at the time of its closing? How many families were in the congregation at the time of its closing? How many families were in the congregation at the time of its closing?

8. Is this first building still in use? If not, tell why it is not used now, and what happened to it.

9. When did you have a resident clergyman? 1903

Where did he come from? Grace Methodist

That provision was made for living quarters for him—a residence built, etc.?

10. Did any other denomination use this church building for services? No

Describe the arrangement.

11. Tell what other churches were built in your community, either before your church was built, or any time since. Give dates if possible, denomination of church, and any changes which have occurred in the place of the building—that is, if some denomination other than yours who built it is now using the church, or if it is used for some other purpose.

Grace Methodist was the first church in Saugus about 1889.

Are all these churches in town? If not, give distances from town, and from one another.

If not built in town, why were they not built there?
5. If you had a church building, give the date it was built.

Who designed the building? Church was St. Paul's 1903

Who built it?

What material was it made of? Wood

How many people did it seat?

What was the name and denomination of the church? 300 St. Paul, 86

6. Describe the steps taken in arranging for the building of the church, telling who started it, how money was secured, etc.

7. How many families were engaged in the work? How much was raised? How much was needed? How much was left over?

8. Is this first building still in use? If not, tell why it is not used now, and what happened to it.

9. When did you have a resident clergyman? 1903

10. Did any other denomination use this church building for services? No

Describe the arrangement.

11. Tell what other churches were built in your community, whether before your church was built, or any time since. Give dates if possible, denomination of church, and any changes which have occurred in the same. If the building is still there, describe it; if not, give its location.

Are all these churches in town? Yes

If not built in town, why were they not built there?
12. Was your church established as a home mission? Describe the arrangements as to finance, student ministers, etc.

It was hard to understand how the minister lived if he didn't believe in the Lord. If families did not have a church of their own denomination in the community, all they usually go to some other church, or not attend at all?

13. If families did not have a church of their own denomination in the community, did they usually go to some other church, or not attend at all?

Old folks' day was held every Sunday afternoon in the home. It was a day for everyone to come together and enjoy each other's company. If there was no public religious service?

14. How often and at what time were services held in the church, school or other building? Every week

15. Did Laymen conduct church services when a clergymen was not available? Describe the circumstances.

A Roman Catholic woman, Mrs. Harrington, did and Geo Harvey, an anglican, held the funeral service.

16. Did you have an organ for the service? Yes. When played it? Every one

When was it bought? 1870

How was the money raised for it?

17. Did you have a choir? Yes. How many were in it? 25

Who started it?

Were any of the persons who led the choir or sang in it trained musicians? Explain.

And was the new organ a P.S. Smith?

On the evening of the Baptist Church service, was any other kind of music or musical instruments used in the service?

Describe.

18. What kind of religious instruction for the young, such as Sunday School or catechism classes, were held? Give dates when they were started.

How often were they begun?

How many children attended?

Who was in charge of these and helped with the teaching?

all the adults

19. What organization (or organizations) was formed to help with the support of the church?

What year was it started? 1890

How often did it meet?

How many members belonged to it? 15 or more
12. Was your church established as a home mission?
Describe the arrangements as to finance, student ministers, etc.

It was hard to understand how the missionary
would get paid if they didn't believe there was more than one
in the community. Did they usually go to some other church or not attend at all?

13. If families did not have a church of their own denomination in the com-
munity, did they usually go to some other church or not attend at all?

14. How often and at what time were services held in the church, school, or
other building? Every week

15. Did laymen conduct church services when a clergyman was not available?
Describe the circumstances.

a. Roman Catholic Church, Mrs. Harrington
b. Methodist Church, Mr. Smith

16. Did you have an organ? For the services? Yes

When was it bought? 1874
How was the money raised for it? By subscription

17. Did you have a choir? Yes
How many were in it? 25
Who started it?
Were any of the persons who led the choir or sang in it trained musicians?
Explain. Better than New York, a P.E. college

18. Was there any other kind of music or musical instruments used in the services?
Describe.

19. What kind of religious instruction for the young, such as Sunday School or
Catechism classes, were held? Give dates when they were started.
How often were they held?
How many children attended?
Who was in charge of these and helped with the teaching? All the adults

20. What organization (or organizations) was formed to help with the support of
the church?
What year was it started? 1870
How often did it meet?
How many women or men belonged to it? 15 or more
21. In what year was the first church picnic held? 1897

Describe the church picnics of early days, telling how easy it was to eat and drink, what amusements there were, changes which occurred in later years, and any other details about them which you remember. (There are questions on the Pioneer Recreation Questionnaire dealing with picnics so if you wish to give the information there, you need not repeat it here.)

22. In what year was the first fowl supper or bazaar held? 1890

Has it been held every year after that? Nearly

What differences do you notice between the dishes served at the suppers in the early days and those served now?

What differences are there in serving methods (help yourself, plates served already filled, etc.)?

What changes are there in the price of suppers?

Describe any changes which you have noticed in the needlework offered for sale, in type of work or articles brought, those that were most popular at various times, changes in prices, or any other details which you may remember.

Was a concert of some kind held in connection with the suppers or bazaars in the first years? Mostly

23. Describe any other activities that were carried on to assist in raising money for the church.

Boys were out as the Methodist we all against it called gambling

24. Name any other organizations or meetings associated with the church, telling when they were started, how often they met, and their purpose and activities.

25. Then was any plan of systematic giving for the support of the church and other expenses adopted? No, and then was adopted from apaid many of the ministers' salaries

Of what nature, - weekly envelopes, etc.

Their meals
21. In what year was the first church picnic held? 1837

Describe the church picnics of early days, telling how many attended, what you had to eat and drink, what amusements there were, changes which occurred in later years, and any other details about them which you remember. (There are questions on the Pioneer Recreation Questionnaire dealing with picnics; so if you wish to give the information there, you need not repeat it here.)

22. In what year was the first fall supper or bazaar held? 1840

Was it held every year after that? Yes

What differences do you notice between the dishes served at the suppers in the early days and those served now?

Better than before

What differences are there in serving methods (help yourself, plates served already filled, etc.)?

What changes are there in the price of suppers?

Describe any changes which you have noticed in the needlework offered for sale. In type of work or articles brought, those that were most popular at various times, changes in prices, or any other details which you may remember.

Her needle work can compare with later dates, thus work master piece

Was a concert of some kind held in connection with the suppers or bazaars in the first years? Yes

23. Describe any other activities that were carried on to assist in raising money for the church.

Boys were out as the Methodists we all against it called gambling

24. Name any other organizations or meetings associated with the church, telling when they were started, how often they met, and their purpose and activities.

25. Was there any plan of systematic giving for the support of the church and clergyman adopted? No real plan was adopted

Of what nature, - weekly envelopes, gifts, apaid many of the ministers salaries

35. Describe any special features or unusual influences of pioneer churches or anything connected with it which you found interesting. (Use other sheets, or back of this sheet if necessary.)

27. How far did some of the people have to travel to church services? 7 miles.

That means of travel was used? Horse.

All were represented all nations.

We all behaved as one of the old times were sent to fail only one and he got you for playing a trick on his neighbor.
